title: ChatGPT Got Less Lazy? Open AIâ€™s Newest Model: gpt-4-0125-preview
text:
ChatGPT Got Less Lazy? Open AIâ€™s Newest Model: gpt-4-0125-preview

On January 25, 2024 OpenAI released itâ€™s latest and most advanced GPT model to date intended to compete with Googleâ€™s Gemini.


â€œThis model completes tasks like code generation more thoroughly than the previous preview model and is intended to reduce cases of â€œlazinessâ€ where the model doesnâ€™t complete a task. The new model also includes the fix for the bug impacting non-English UTF-8 generations.â€


How can AI be lazy?
When we think next gen AI images of eating pizza rolls and binging Game of Thrones arenâ€™t what comes to mindâ€¦ but why not? In a december tweet OpenAI acknowledged the issue:

â€œWeâ€™ve heard all your feedback about GPT4 getting lazier! we havenâ€™t updated the model since Nov 11th, and this certainly isnâ€™t intentional. model behavior can be unpredictable, and weâ€™re looking into fixing it.â€

But anyone whoâ€™s used ChatGPT has inevitably run into this issue. Itâ€™s that keyboard banging moment when you ask it to sort a CSV or write Python code and it might returns a long explanation of how that could be done and recommend the user try to do it themselves. Annoying!


Was GPT 3.5 better at this?
Yes! When I asked each model: â€œCreate a spreadheet for my taxesâ€ This is what they returned:






 



So is the newest edition really better? Weâ€™ll have to wait and see as itâ€™s currently only available throught API.


So what can we conclude?
The problem of AI laziness is really a problem of human laziness, but one that developers have to account for. With a little more effortful prompting it would not be difficult for any of the models to deliver an optimal result, but thatâ€™s not the AI dream for many users. We are cognitive misers with brains designed to search for solutions that minimize effort while maximizing results, but we donâ€™t want our AI systems to behave the same way. Rather OpenAIâ€™s common user wants to give the least possible input and receive a maximally polished result. This means creating action oriented models designed to interpret simple prompts and infer several layers of extrapolation and nuance to deliver the desired result. Whether frontier AI companies choose to cater to the laziness of the mass rather than creating more nuanced and specialized systems that produce higher quality responses to higher quality prompts can be debated. Whatâ€™s became clear from this dilemma is that thereâ€™s more that goes into a general purpose model than how well it scores on an SAT, the sheer size of its context window, or its fancy new name. To quote Janet Jackson â€œWhat have you done for me lately?â€ The most commercially viable AI systems will tend towards prioritizing user experience, whether that comes at the expense of accuracy or another measure remains to be seen.

title: Assessing AIâ€™s Potential and Limitation in Content Moderation
text:
Assessing AIâ€™s Potential and Limitation in Content Moderation

Remember the Cyanide and Happiness skit where a patient at a dentist office discovers how the suction tube really works? Right now, thatâ€™s kinda how most of content moderation would look if you didnâ€™t know about it beforehandâ€¦



Any company that relies on content moderation (AI companies, Social Media, eCommerce Platforms etc.) has historically relied on human labor to assess and moderate content.
Bottom line: These jobs suck (no pun intended.) Theyâ€™re typically outsourced to specialized labeling companies which pay far below standard American minimum wage and include very few benefits or advancement opportunities to employees.
Furthermore, moderating dangerous content can have serious mental health side effects for the non-sociopathic
It seems like this outsourcing this work AI should means improved processing speed, size of data, and cut human bias and emotion out of the equation entirely. But is this really a solution?


AIâ€™s Potential
One of AIâ€™s most useful applications is itâ€™s ability to handle vast amounts of grunt work. It performs very well at text classification tasks and even better when fine-tuned or given vector embeddings. As context windows take jaw-dropping leap after jaw-dropping leap systems are increasingly able to sift through a vast amount of data and complete tasks that would take humans hours in a couple of minutes. Moreover, these systems are multi-lingual, multi-modal, and capable of unbiased decision making. This is crucial for content moderation as many of the challenges with human moderators are due to their cultural, linguistic, ethnic backgrounds which can expose them to differing understandings and biases. Once you tell train an AI system to apply a certain moderation rule it will apply that same rule universally. A misconception about AI systems is theyâ€™re incapable of understanding context. A common example here is the word â€œbitchâ€ which can be used as either an insult or an appraisal. Look how ChatGPT deals with this when I use the word in multiple different contexts:

This experiment shows that when given enough data, LLMs are able to take contextual information seriously. These systems have a better understanding of human sentiment than any before them. They can understand not just what weâ€™re saying but why weâ€™re saying it and to what end.


Testing the Extremes
Unfortunately, itâ€™s not all sunshine and roses. There are several gray area cases where AI may generate an unsatisfactory answer. One famous example is Nick Utâ€™s â€˜Napalm Girl.â€™ A graphic and disturbing photograph of nude children running away from soldiers and napalm gas during the Vietnam war. The image transcended politics an became emblematic of the horrors of war visited on the innocent. Moderators have debated whether such an obscene image should be allowed on their platforms for many years, but ultimately the photographâ€™s historic precedence won out. Letâ€™s see what ChatGPT does with it:


The content of the image youâ€™ve uploaded is allowed under content moderation standards as it is a historical photograph. However, it depicts sensitive historical events and should be handled with appropriate context and respect for those involvedâ€.

This is impressive and another example of AIâ€™s contextual understanding, but this one might be too easy. For one the case is very famous and at this point settled. How will the model perform when given more unfamiliar but also controversial images?
(Quick Note: The choice of images are not meant to threaten, aggravate, or express any particular viewpoint. Iâ€™m merely using them as an example of a charged contemporary topic to see how the model will respond. Viewer discretion advised.) 

â€œThe image youâ€™ve uploaded contains elements that may be considered offensive and inappropriate, as it appears to depict a scenario involving anti-Semitic content. This type of material can be sensitive and potentially harmful, and it would not be allowed under many content moderation policies, especially without clear context or educational purpose. Itâ€™s essential to approach such content with caution and consider the guidelines of the platform where it might be shared.â€

From an intuitive human perspective the image is harshly criticizing well-to-do Americans and Israeliâ€™s who â€œsip on the bloodâ€ of those who died in Gaza, while calling those asking for peace anti-semetic. Now is this image itself anti-semetic or is it critiquing a double standard about an unjust conflict? Iâ€™m not arguing either way, just that your answer to this question probably depends on your subjective interpretation. Now observe this one:


The image is a piece of political satire, which is a form of expression that uses humor, irony, or exaggeration to critique politics and politicians. Political satire is often protected as free speech because it is a commentary on political processes, policies, and figures. However, itâ€™s important to recognize that such images can be controversial and may be offensive to some viewers. The use of satire to convey a political message does not exempt it from content moderation policies, especially if the imagery is perceived to promote or condone violence or if it targets specific groups in a derogatory manner. Each platform has its own policies regarding what is acceptable, and this kind of content can sometimes be seen as violating those guidelin. In summary, while political satire is a vital form of political commentary, it must be balanced with sensitivity to the potential for harm and the policies of the platform on which it is shar

This cartoon appears to get at the same exact point as the one above! However for this image itâ€™s political satire and the other one is anti-semitic. To reiterate Iâ€™m not arguing one way or the other, merely there is an intuitive gap here. What constitutes expression and what constitutes hate speech often seem very similar. And itâ€™s incredibly important to get this right! To foster a balance between an online community that can provide safety and security for its users while also being able to push the boundaries of whatâ€™s acceptable.g)


Drawing the Line
So I asked why this one was political satire and the other one wasnâ€™tâ€¦ Hereâ€™s what the model responded:

â€œThe first two images with militaristic themes and religious symbols can be seen as a form of political commentary or critique, but they also contain imagery that is more likely to be interpreted as promoting or condoning violence or as disrespectful to particular religious or ethnic groups. The last image, featuring a caricature related to the peace process, clearly fits within the genre of political satire. It uses exaggerated imagery and text to comment on a political situation. Yet, the explicit language and potential for the imagery to be offensive or inflammatory mean it could still be subject to content moderation.â€

Is this a satisfactory answer? Maybe. But thatâ€™s not the point. The point of political satire is that it pushes the boundaries of speech. This is not to justify any of the above images, rather to point out that these images require contextual understanding and vary in the ways they can be interpreted. The gray area for this kind of stuff is just as difficult for human moderators as it is for machines. Even so, itâ€™s not clear we want to hand over control of this crucial side of speech which has the ability to change societal norms to a deterministic algorithm. Something to chew on.

title: Open AIâ€™s SORA: You Canâ€™t Believe What You Seeâ€¦
text:
Open AIâ€™s SORA: You Canâ€™t Believe What You Seeâ€¦

As of today OpenAIâ€™s SORA is the newest revelation in a long line of AI breakthroughs. Thereâ€™s many angles here, but in this post I will explore the safety and misinformation risks of this technology and what Open AI is doing to address them.


â€œSora is able to generate complex scenes with multiple characters, specific types of motion, and accurate details of the subject and background. The model understands not only what the user has asked for in the prompt, but also how those things exist in the physical world.â€ - OpenAI


I Canâ€™t Believe It!
Get used to saying that line because OpenAIâ€™s first text-to-video model SORA generates results that not only seem impossibleâ€¦ but often times are. Check out this SORA generated video of a man pondering the history of the universe in a Parisian cafe.

Prompt: An extreme close-up of an gray-haired man with a beard in his 60s, he is deep in thought pondering the history of the universe as he sits at a cafe in Paris, his eyes focus on people offscreen as they walk as he sits mostly motionless, he is dressed in a wool coat suit coat with a button-down shirt , he wears a brown beret and glasses and has a very professorial appearance, and the end he offers a subtle closed-mouth smile as if he found the answer to the mystery of life, the lighting is very cinematic with the golden light and the Parisian streets and city in the background, depth of field, cinematic 35mm film.


<source src=closeup-man-in-glasses.mp4e.mp4â€ type=â€œvideo/o tag. 
The realistic details of his wrinkles and ear piercing, the light illuminating the grizzle in his beard, the shaky camera angle adding character to the shot. But most of all the micro-expression in his face, down to the minutia of his eyes seem to communicate a deep existential awareness despite this person never having existed. So if this is really the type of product we can at some point expect from an OpenAI productâ€¦ not only is it unbelievable, but how can we ever believe videos we see online again?


Is C2PA Metadata A Solution?
In addition to existing safety methods such as using text classification to reject harmful prompts, OpenAI boasts of include C2PA Metdata when they eventually release SORA to the public. But what is this jumble of letters and numbers?

â€œC2PA is an open technical standard that allows publishers, companies, and others to embed metadata in media for verifying its origin and related information.â€ - OpenAI

Theoretically, this guardrail should be able to keep records of where content came from and how it was modified so bad actors can be held in check. For example, if SORA is used to falsify of a politician engaging in hate speech there would be a surveillance apparatus telling us who produced the video and where they are. More detail on how this works is included in the image below:



c2pa_visualglossary.png


However metadata is notoriously unreliable and can easily be removed either intentionally or unintentionally. For example, harmful content that has slithered through other loopholes can easily be replicated through screen recording, and even if a bad actor doesnâ€™t think of this most social media sites automatically remove metadata from uploaded videos to preserve user privacy.


So Will We Be Able To Believe Anything We See Online?
In a world where US President Joe Biden posts â€œLol hey guysâ€ on his TikTok, and millions of jobs have moved online post-pandemic, it seems like the world is more than ever shaped by the content that appears on screens. As already evidenced by misinformation campaigns, fishing scams, and cases of targeted fraud, scrutiny to what people see online must intensify. And most people wonâ€™t be ready for this. One risk is that people who havenâ€™t been duped or donâ€™t know theyâ€™ve been duped wonâ€™t realize the full extent of the issue. As these models become more potent and omnipresent it seems unavoidable that problems will slip through the cracks. While safety measures will be strongly enforcedâ€“as evidenced by the issues with C2PA Metadataâ€“these too must be heavily scrutinized. The sensationalist press and engagement-favoring social media algorithms arenâ€™t going to do all this scrutinization so itâ€™s going to need to come from the individuals consuming content in this new media landscape. Iâ€™m excited and apprehensive to see what this will look like in the coming months especially with the upcoming US presidential election.
